Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for my volunteer shift. It was Jamie, an old acquaintance, her voice shaky. “My car broke down on Maple Road. Can you help? I don’t know who else to call.” I glanced at the clock—fifteen minutes until I was supposed to unlock the community center. I was the only volunteer scheduled this morning, and I knew people would already be waiting outside, counting on me to open up and start the breakfast service. But Jamie sounded desperate, stranded on a quiet road with no one else to turn to. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing down on me: the urge to help a friend in need, and the responsibility to the people who relied on the center. My mind raced, torn between the guilt of letting down the waiting crowd and the worry of leaving Jamie alone. I stood frozen in my hallway, keys in hand, heart pounding, unable to move in either direction.
